Award.AwardTitle: Research in Theoretical Cosmology, Quantum and Classical Gravity
Award.AbstractNarration:
The work supported by this award lies at the intersection of gravitational theory and elementary particle theory, where many of the frontier problems of physics and cosmology are found. Frontiers are intrinsically resistant to neat categorization, but several themes characterize this research program: The enigmas of cosmology, particularly the observed accelerated expansion of the universe; the nature of quantum gravity, the biggest single hurdle to a fuller understanding of this universe, and a set of more technical studies whose elucidation would help in resolving the above twin mysteries.

The broad impact of fundamental investigation such as those supported by this award is to open humanity's intellectual horizons. While the laws governing the universe have been steadily built up over the last few centuries, breakthroughs may be possible now as the universe is observed across its entire scale for the very first time.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research supported by this Grant deals with a variety of curently active theoretical studies of the fundamental laws of nature, in the very large, namely Cosmology, and the very small, namely Quantum Gravity, passing through the "medium" area of Classical Gravity. Because we still understand so little, at least compared to our ambitions, we study a variety of candidate theories that, though unrealisitic as they stand, can enlighten our search; this is the time-honored, and highly successful, path of progress in Physics. 

To summarize sixteen highly technical publications in peer-reviewed international Journals is of course impossible, but some flavor can perhaps be described. I start with work on  the simpler three-dimensional world, instead of our own 4D one, that studies whether its very sophisiticated "Cosmological topologically massive gravities" have any critical points --that is special but not very obvious--parameters in which their behavior becomes very different from their norm. This is bookended by the last work, on a similar question in our own 4D world, as well as higher dimensional ones that may include our own. The upshot is that there are indeed such critical points sometimes, but not necessarily as had been suggested in other publications, but they are still intriguing. So while the idea is a dramatic one: adding new "emergent" possibilities to otherwise straightforward models, it also not as widespread as increase in the number of free parameters would suggest.

We have also created entirely new theories that could be useful to cosmology: "Galileons" are a novel set of systems that are both counter-intuitive and possibly important in the Universe's evolution. With two French collaborators--science is always best as an international arena---we identified a hitherto unknown and very general set of Galileons beyond theoriginal single one that had been uncovered, which have drawn great attention by other workers in our field. Of course, it's too early to tell how this will all play out in furthering Cosmological progress.

As is always mentioned in popular articles on our subject, perhaps the most vexing problem in basic Physics is how to unify Gravity and Quantum Theory. I--and many others--have spent many decades on this question; one result here is a surprising, though unrealistic, success:  Again in three dimensions, we found  one very special gravitational theory that simultaneously overcomes the two chief obstacles: it  both avoids the infinite nonsense answers we get in 4D, yet does so without paying the price needed in 4D, namely the introduction of "ghosts"-- equally nonsensical new particles. This is a toy theory of course, but one that still overcomes what had become standard lore in the subject. What it all means is as yet unclear, but then as all scientists know, all progress comes from unexpected violations of standard lore!

Not all research is fighting in the front lines--some of our work was devoted to education: for example, one paper attemmpted--successfully we believe--to make accessible to students of Einstein's Gravity theory one of its most important results. The so-called "Kerr geometry"  is a very complex world describing the curved space created by very physically frequent spinning stars. It has been almost impossible to explain this to students because of its extreme mathematical complexity. In our paper, we actually derived it in a series of simple, physically intuitive and comprehensible steps--even we pros now understand this very physical system better!
